prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The spectral setup is consistent with that of Csengeri et al (project 2015.1.00162.S), in order to produce a directly comparable data set. The latter project is based on a complementary sample of IR-dark sources.

The scale to be resolved is the fragmentation scale within a massive dense clump, which is expected to be of order the Jeans length assuming T=10K (dV = 0.3 km/s)and density 10^6 cm^-3, which is ~ 0.01pc. The maximum distance in the sample is 4 kpc, at which 0.01 pc = 0.5", to separate structures on this scale this requires resolutions of ~0.1", allowing for uncertainty in density and variations in source elevation. ATLASGAL compact sources are somewhat resolved in the APEX 19" beam at 870um, probably due to clups having power-law radial surface-brightness distributions and structures signifciantly larger that 10" will be detected in the ATLASGAL data and other sub-mm observations. We expect to find much more compact sources within clumps surrounded by a diffuse envelope on size scales of ~10".
The ACA is required to recover emission on larger angular scales and link to the single-beam data.

Sensitivity considerations are based on continuum fluxes. With standard dust absorption coefficient, a 1 mJy 870um continuum source at 4kpc will have mass ~ 0.2 Msun if T=10K (~0.05 Msun at T=20K). A target continuum rms of 0.3mJy per pointing will produce 0.2 mJy where the beams overlap in the grid centre. This therefore gives at least ~25-sigma detections of 1-Msun compact sources, enough to detect any low-mass cores present within the high-mass clumps.
For the spectral setup, baseband 4 is set for a relatively line-free region and assigned to continuum, baseband 3 covers the C17O 3-2 line and several CH3OH lines. Baseband 2 includes the 12CO 3-2 line and well as HC13N 4-3 H13CO+ 4-3 and several others. Baseband 1 is set for SiO 8-7 along with HN13C 4-3. This tuning is mainly selected for consistency with the Csengeri et al project 2015.1.00162.S

The spectral setup is consistent with that of Csengeri et al (project 2015.1.00162.S) which is underway, in order to produce a directly comparable data set. The latter project is based on a complementary sample of IR-dark sources.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: The Urquhart et al sample of young massive star-forming regions is the most comprehensive sample of such sources in existence covering two orders of magnitude in mass and three in luminosity. The form of the mass-luminosity relationship of the sample suggests that the star-forming efficiency within the host clumps is a function of the clump mass and that the highest mass stars in the embedded young clusters form significantly earlier than the low-mass component. We propose to test this model by observing a representative subset of the Urquhart sources in order to detect the substructure (cores) within each clump and measure its mass spectrum, to determine whether the low-mass cores that will produce the low-mass stars are present and to determine the ratio of core mass to total clump mass as a function of the latter. We require ALMA in order to reach angular resolutions of ~0.1" and resolve the likely Jeans length while reaching sensitivities sufficient to detect cores of <1 solar mass. We will observe the band-7 continuum and several molecular emission lines, to measure kinematic properties of the embedded cluster and to look for accretion flows in the core envelope gas.

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Astrophysics Research Institute, Liverpool John Moores University

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: School of Physics, Astronomy and Mathematics, Hertfordshire, University of
